newsitem.title: SRI LANKA: CRICKET-RAIN COMES TO ZIMBABWE'S RESCUE AGAINST SRI LANKA.
newsitem.headline: CRICKET-RAIN COMES TO ZIMBABWE'S RESCUE AGAINST SRI LANKA.

text.p: Rain hindered Sri Lanka's push
for victory after they forced Zimbabwe to follow on on the third
day of the first test on Friday.
Play was possible only in the afternoon session during which
Zimbabwe, resuming at 105 for six in reply to Sri Lanka's first
innings 349, were dismissed for 145.
They were 20 without loss in their second innings when rain
return to wash out play for the day.
Only Craig Wishart defied Sri Lanka's pace and spin attack
for any length of time to score a resolute 51, hitting a six and
two fours in his 157-ball innings.
The rest of the Zimbabwe late order succumbed to the spin of
Muthiah Muralitharan and Jayantha Silva after left-arm paceman
Chaminda Vaas provided the initial breakthrough by having Craig
Evans caught behind for nine.
Muralitharan accounted for the wicket of Paul Strang for six
and Silva was left on a hat-trick after picking up the last two
Zimbabwe wickets off successive deliveries.
Left-arm spinner Silva whose only previous test appearance
was against Australia last year, first had Wishart caught off a
drive to mid-off and off the next delivery, bowled after a
10-minute break for rain, had Andrew Whittall caught by Kumara
Dharmasena at square leg.
Silva finished with a test best of three for 10 off 14.5
overs, which included nine maidens, while Muralitharan's two
wickets cost him 28 runs off 24 overs. Vaas was Sri Lanka's
leading wicket-taker with four for 73, which also included his
50th in test cricket.
Zimbabwe openers Grant Flower and Mark Dekker survived 30
minutes batting in the second innings but the visitors face an
uphill task of trying to bat out the next two days with rain as
their best hope of salvation.
